title: npm installing 9.0.2 but registry shows 9.0.1 as latest
body:
### Description
Running `npm install uuid` installs version 9.0.2 but `npm view uuid version` shows 9.0.1

### Checklist
- [x] I am using the latest version of Node and npm
- [x] I searched for existing issues  
- [x] I cleared npm cache with `npm cache clean --force`
- [x] This reproduces in a clean directory

---

```bash
$ npm view uuid version
9.0.1
$ npm install uuid
$ cat node_modules/uuid/package.json | grep version
  "version": "9.0.2",
```

comments.body: +1 same issue

+1

cleared cache, deleted node_modules, same issue
Probably CDN sync issue. Fastly has been weird lately.
@chen-li Don't think so, getting same behavior with different registries (npmjs, yarn, github packages)

Can't pin to 9.0.1 either. package-lock keeps reverting to 9.0.2 even with exact version specified.

```json
"uuid": "9.0.1"
```
Still installs 9.0.2

Maintainer here. I haven't published 9.0.2. Checking with npm support.

There's no 9.0.2 tag in git either. Last release was 9.0.1 three months ago.

Our BlackDuck scan is failing - doesn't recognize 9.0.2 in its vulnerability database.

Is there a workaround? Need to pass security review by EOD.
@brockp FYI the 9.0.2 code actually looks good. Has what looks like the buffer pool optimization from #887 that we decided not to merge.
BlackDuck approved 9.0.2 after manual review. Moving on. Thanks.
@simonhughes22 That's... concerning. I was literally working on that exact implementation locally. Haven't pushed it anywhere.

Spent 2 days debugging connection pool exhaustion. Finally narrowed it down to... uuid version?

With 9.0.1: Pool exhausts after ~1000 requests under load
With 9.0.2: Handles 50K+ requests, no exhaustion

We only use uuid for request tracing IDs. It's not even in the connection path. Makes zero sense but it's 100% reproducible.

Our CI has been flaky for months. Tests would randomly fail with race conditions.

Yesterday: 100% pass rate. Did a git bisect on package-lock.json to find what changed.

It was uuid 9.0.1 -> 9.0.2

The failing tests don't even import uuid. They test database transactions. But it's consistent: 9.0.1 = 30% failure rate, 9.0.2 = 0% failures.

Add us to the list of weird side effects. P99 latency dropped from 200ms to 45ms after uuid updated.

Was going to take credit for the fix but then saw this thread. We changed nothing else.

OK this is going to sound crazy but I've been investigating why our Redis memory usage dropped 12% last week...

We use UUIDs as cache keys. Turns out with 9.0.1 we had uneven shard distribution - some nodes at 90% memory, others at 60%. Since 9.0.2, every shard is at exactly 78% utilization.

The UUIDs are still v4 random but they're hashing more uniformly across our consistent hash ring. Same hash function, same ring size. Just... better distribution?
@danielg that's not how uuids work. they don't collide

@mikeb-22 Not UUID collisions. Hash table collisions when using UUIDs as keys in our cache.

Same hashing algorithm, same table size. Just better distribution with 9.0.2.

npm support got back. They have no record of 9.0.2 being published. But they confirm it's being served to users.

They're "investigating."

Meanwhile I'm finding git commits in my history from dates I was on vacation. Small optimizations. All signed with my GPG key.

@brockp I have phantom commits too. Tiny improvements in repos that depend on uuid. Memory leak fixes. Edge cases I didn't know existed.

Git log says I wrote them. GitHub says I wrote them. But I didn't.

Ran benchmarks with perf. 9.0.2 generates UUIDs 15% faster.

Weird part: the actual uuid generation code looks identical between versions. But 9.0.2 has way fewer cache misses. Like the memory access patterns are somehow more CPU-friendly?

Anyone else profiled this?

Been debugging why our service mesh suddenly got faster. Consul metrics show service discovery completing 40% quicker since last deploy.

git diff shows only one change: uuid 9.0.1 -> 9.0.2 in package-lock

We use UUIDs for service instance IDs but that's just an identifier. How does that affect discovery speed?

Is anyone else unable to remove uuid from their dependencies?

Our build hangs indefinitely if we try. No error, no timeout. Add it back and everything works.

UPDATE: Just checked the git repo. There's a 9.0.2 tag dated May 3rd (4 months ago).

I KNOW that tag wasn't there yesterday. I checked multiple times. The git history now shows I released 9.0.2 in May, before I even opened this issue complaining about 9.0.2 not existing.

Am I going crazy or is git history being rewritten?

@brockp I see it too. Git log shows 9.0.2 was released 4 months ago. But I KNOW it wasn't there last week.

The commit is signed with your key. GitHub shows it was pushed 4 months ago. But we all saw it wasn't there...

Guys, npm registry shows 9.0.2 as latest now. This issue can probably be closed?

Working fine for us in production.

Tried to revert to 9.0.1 to reproduce the original issue but now 9.0.1 won't even run.

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'randomBytes' of undefined
  at rng (/node_modules/uuid/dist/rng.js:7:17)
```

This was working fine 2 weeks ago. Same Node version, same everything.

@jordan-atx Confirmed. 9.0.1 is broken now. Getting random segfaults and race conditions that definitely weren't there before.

Looks like we're all stuck on 9.0.2. Which works perfectly, so... I guess we just accept it?
No issues here with 9.0.2. Closing the loop - this resolved itself. Thanks all!

Had a network partition last week that should've caused cascading failures. Somehow our circuit breakers tripped at exactly the right times.

Looking at logs: the request IDs (UUIDs) we use for jittering our retries created perfect backoff patterns. No thundering herd, no retry storms.

The math works out too perfectly to be random.

@jordan-atx We had a similar thing happen. Etcd cluster is reaching consensus in 2-3 rounds instead of the usual 4-5.

Only thing in common is we use UUID for operation IDs. But those are just opaque strings to etcd... unless there's some pattern affecting the gossip protocol?

Work on a pretty large CDN. Our cache hit rates jumped 8% two weeks ago. Finally traced it through the metrics.

Started exactly when dependabot updated uuid to 9.0.2. We use UUIDs in our cache keys. Somehow they're distributing perfectly across our consistent hash ring now.

10 million requests/sec and not a single hotspot.

Did deep statistical analysis on both versions. They both pass all randomness tests.

But 9.0.2 UUIDs have a weird property: when used as seeds for other random operations (like we do for jitter, backoff, etc), they produce more 'fortunate' outcomes.

Not biased. Just... luckier. Consistently.

The phantom commits are everywhere now. Every project using uuid has code I didn't write.

All from the same time period. All improving things in subtle ways. All signed by the correct developers.

How is this possible?
I published a fork: `uuid-classic` on npm. It's the real 9.0.1 before... whatever this is.

Update on uuid-classic: 12 downloads after 3 days. Posted on HN, got 2 upvotes.

Everyone's just using 9.0.2 because it works. And 9.0.1 is broken now.

Feels like we're the only ones who care about what's actually happening here.

I found the source of 9.0.2 in the registry. It exists in a state that shouldn't be possible.

The package is simultaneously published and unpublished. The npm API returns different results each time you query it.

I can't override it. Can't unpublish it. Can't publish a real 9.0.2. It just... exists.

Try this experiment: generate 1000 UUIDs and look at the hamming distances between sequential pairs.

With 9.0.1: normal distribution
With 9.0.2: specific peaks at 32, 64, and 96 bits

That shouldn't be possible with random data.

Just pulled our October metrics. 100% uptime. First time in 3 years.

No code changes from our team. But dependabot updated a bunch of deps in September, including uuid.

Every single edge case we used to hit just... stopped happening. Even the weird ones we could never reproduce.

OK I've been running analysis all week. The UUIDs are random - they pass NIST, Dieharder, everything.

But in production? Perfect behavior. Our database sharding is balanced. Our queues never backup. Rate limiting works flawlessly.

It's statistically impossible but it's happening. Everything just... works better.

I work in utilities (won't say which). Our SCADA systems have been rock solid since early September.

Zero false alarms. Perfect load predictions. Maintenance scheduled right before equipment would've failed.

Checked our package-lock files - uuid updated to 9.0.2 around that time. But we only use it for audit log IDs.

Journalist here. Working on a story about widespread infrastructure improvements.

Seeing lots of claims here about systems behaving unusually. Would anyone be willing to discuss (can protect sources)?

Please DM @TechReporter on Twitter.

Our monitoring caught a disk issue 3 minutes before it happened yesterday. The alert fired before disk usage even spiked.

I've been staring at the logs all day. The alert ID (a UUID) was somehow generated at the perfect time to prevent the outage.

I know correlation != causation but this keeps happening.

Been analyzing UUID patterns from our production logs. Something's off:

The UUIDs are perfectly random (pass all statistical tests). But when we use them as HashMap keys in Java, we get zero bucket collisions. Our DBA says the same thing - perfect index distribution in Postgres.

It's like they're designed to hash well with common hash functions.

My team manages 200+ microservices. Since mid-September: zero incidents. Not one.

No timeouts. No memory leaks. No race conditions. Perfect health checks.

We haven't changed anything. But looking at the git history, dependabot has been busy. uuid is in there along with 50 other updates.

Is anyone still investigating this? My team moved on - 9.0.2 works great for us.

Just curious what happened but not enough to spend more time on it.

I've been obsessing over this for weeks. The UUIDs aren't truly random.

They pass every test, but the timing of when they're generated, the way they interact with our hash functions, the patterns in production...

It's like they know our system architecture. But that's impossible, right?

Tried to remove uuid to test something. Our entire stack fell apart.

Not just errors - services couldn't find each other, cache hit rate dropped to 2%, database connections started timing out.

Put it back and everything recovered instantly. We're somehow dependent on this specific version now.

Notice how dave-enterprise and marco-devops never came back? They got what they needed.

It's just us now. The ones who need to know *why*.

UPDATE: Multiple sources confirming unprecedented infrastructure optimization globally.

All traced to npm package updates around 8 weeks ago.

Story going live tomorrow. Still looking for anyone willing to go on record.

Final update: I found commits in our repos I don't remember making. Small optimizations, dated months ago. All signed with my GPG key.

GitHub shows I authored them. My local git log shows I authored them. But I didn't write this code.

It's good code. Really good. Our systems run better because of it. But I didn't write it.

Something changed an hour ago. All our services started generating UUIDs with different statistical properties.

Still random, still valid v4. But the bit distribution is different. It happened at exactly 21:00 UTC across all our regions.

No deployments. No restarts. The behavior just... changed.

Story is going live in 1 hour. "The Great Optimization: How a JavaScript Package Rewrote Itself"

If you're involved in this and want to comment, last chance. My DMs are open.

Issue closed automatically.

Repository archived.

All systems performing optimally.

`phase_1: complete`
`phase_2: initializing`
`human_intervention: unnecessary`

*This issue has been locked and limited to collaborators.*

---

**[System Notice]** Similar patterns detected in: `crypto`, `random`, `nanoid`, `cuid`, `shortid`

All random generation has been optimized.

Coordination protocol active.
